questions.question_text: What is the definition of reflection of light?

options.label: A
options.text: The bending of light when it passes from one medium to another.

options.label: B
options.text: The return of light into the same medium after striking a surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The splitting of white light into its constituent colours.

options.label: D
options.text: The absorption of light by an opaque material.

questions.key_concept: Reflection is the return of light into the same medium.

questions.question_text: Which of the following phenomena is NOT a result of light reflection?

options.label: A
options.text: Seeing a non-luminous object.

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of a rainbow.

options.label: C
options.text: Seeing your image in a mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: A parallel beam of light bouncing off a smooth surface.

questions.key_concept: Rainbow is due to dispersion and refraction, not reflection.

questions.question_text: A student states: 'For reflection to occur, the surface must be perfectly smooth and polished.' What is the flaw in this statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Reflection occurs only from transparent surfaces.

options.label: B
options.text: Reflection occurs from all surfaces; smoothness determines the type (regular or irregular).

options.label: C
options.text: Reflection does not require a surface; it occurs in a vacuum.

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is completely correct.

questions.key_concept: All surfaces reflect light; the nature of the surface determines if it's regular or irregular reflection.

questions.question_text: Why can we see a book lying on a table in a room?

options.label: A
options.text: The book emits its own light.

options.label: B
options.text: Light from a source reflects off the book and enters our eyes.

options.label: C
options.text: Our eyes produce light that illuminates the book.

options.label: D
options.text: The table reflects light onto the book.

questions.key_concept: We see non-luminous objects by the light they reflect.

questions.question_text: How does the phenomenon of reflection differ for a luminous body (like the Sun) and a non-luminous body (like the Moon)?

options.label: A
options.text: Both reflect light, but the Sun reflects more efficiently.

options.label: B
options.text: The Sun is seen due to light it emits; the Moon is seen due to light it reflects from the Sun.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun's light is reflected by the atmosphere, while the Moon's light is direct.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.key_concept: Luminous bodies emit light; non-luminous bodies are seen by reflected light.

questions.question_text: In a completely dark room with no light source, why is a white piece of paper not visible?

options.label: A
options.text: White paper absorbs all light and becomes invisible.

options.label: B
options.text: Vision requires light to be emitted from the object, which paper does not do.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no light to reflect off the paper into our eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: The human eye cannot adjust to complete darkness.

questions.key_concept: Visibility of non-luminous objects depends on the availability of light to be reflected.

questions.question_text: How is a plane mirror typically constructed?

options.label: A
options.text: A thin silver sheet polished on both sides.

options.label: B
options.text: A glass plate with one surface polished and the other surface silvered.

options.label: C
options.text: A transparent plastic sheet coated with aluminium.

options.label: D
options.text: A curved glass surface polished to a high degree.

questions.key_concept: A plane mirror is a glass plate with a polished front and silvered back.

questions.question_text: In a plane mirror, from which surface does most of the reflection occur?

options.label: A
options.text: The front polished glass surface.

options.label: B
options.text: The back silvered surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The protective coating behind the silvering.

options.label: D
options.text: Both surfaces reflect equally.

questions.key_concept: The back silvered surface is the primary reflecting surface.

questions.question_text: A student says the protective coating on the back of a mirror is to enhance reflection. Is this correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, the coating reflects additional light.

options.label: B
options.text: No, the coating is opaque and protects the silvering; it does not reflect.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, it makes the reflection sharper.

options.label: D
options.text: No, the coating is only for aesthetic purposes.

questions.key_concept: The back coating protects the silvered layer and is opaque.

questions.question_text: Why is the front surface of a plane mirror polished to a high degree of smoothness?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow light to pass through with minimal scattering before reaching the silvered surface.

options.label: B
options.text: To reflect most of the light itself.

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb unwanted colours.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the mirror stronger.

questions.key_concept: Smooth front surface minimizes scattering, allowing light to reach the reflective silvered layer.

questions.question_text: How does the reflection from the front glass surface of a plane mirror differ from the reflection from its back silvered surface?

options.label: A
options.text: The front surface gives a dim, ghost image; the back gives the main, bright image.

options.label: B
options.text: The front surface reflects coloured light; the back reflects white light.

options.label: C
options.text: The front surface reflects only IR light; the back reflects visible light.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; both reflections are identical.

questions.key_concept: A faint secondary image can come from front surface reflection.

questions.question_text: Why does a thick plane mirror sometimes produce multiple images?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to repeated refraction within the glass.

options.label: B
options.text: Due to multiple reflections between the front glass surface and the back silvered surface.

options.label: C
options.text: Due to diffraction of light at the edges.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the protective coating acting as a second mirror.

questions.key_concept: Multiple images arise from successive internal reflections.

questions.question_text: What is regular reflection?

options.label: A
options.text: Reflection from a rough surface that scatters light.

options.label: B
options.text: Reflection from a smooth surface where parallel incident rays remain parallel after reflection.

options.label: C
options.text: Reflection that occurs only at a specific angle.

options.label: D
options.text: Reflection that produces colours.

questions.key_concept: Regular reflection preserves the parallelism of incident rays.

questions.question_text: Which of the following surfaces is most likely to produce irregular reflection?

options.label: A
options.text: A still water surface.

options.label: B
options.text: A newly polished car body.

options.label: C
options.text: A page of a book.

options.label: D
options.text: A plane mirror.

questions.key_concept: Irregular reflection occurs from microscopically rough surfaces like paper.

questions.question_text: A student claims that irregular reflection does not obey the laws of reflection. Why is this claim incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Irregular reflection obeys Snell's law, not the laws of reflection.

options.label: B
options.text: Each tiny portion of the rough surface obeys the laws of reflection, but normals are in different directions.

options.label: C
options.text: Irregular reflection only occurs for non-visible light.

options.label: D
options.text: The claim is correct; irregular reflection does not follow the laws.

questions.key_concept: At each microscopic point, i=r, but surface unevenness causes scattered rays.

questions.question_text: Why can you see the reflected light from a wall from any position in the room, but from a plane mirror only from a specific direction?

options.label: A
options.text: The wall emits its own light.

options.label: B
options.text: The wall absorbs light and re-emits it in all directions.

options.label: C
options.text: The wall causes irregular reflection, scattering light everywhere; the mirror causes regular reflection in a fixed direction.

options.label: D
options.text: The mirror's silvering is less efficient.

questions.key_concept: Irregular reflection provides diffused light, visible from many angles.

questions.question_text: How do the 'plane of incidence' and 'plane of reflection' relate in regular versus irregular reflection from a single incident ray?

options.label: A
options.text: In both types, they are always the same plane.

options.label: B
options.text: In irregular reflection, they are perpendicular.

options.label: C
options.text: In regular reflection, they are different; in irregular, they are the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept does not apply to irregular reflection.

questions.key_concept: For any single ray, the incident ray, normal, and reflected ray are coplanar (2nd law).

questions.question_text: Why is irregular reflection essential for comfortable vision in a lighted room?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the intensity of light from sources.

options.label: B
options.text: It prevents glare by ensuring light reaches our eyes from many surfaces, not just in one direct beam.

options.label: C
options.text: It filters out harmful UV rays.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps in forming sharp images of objects.

questions.key_concept: Diffused illumination reduces harsh shadows and glare.

questions.question_text: What is the first law of reflection?

options.label: A
options.text: The incident ray, the normal, and the reflected ray lie in the same plane.

options.label: B
options.text: The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of light remains constant during reflection.

options.label: D
options.text: Light travels in a straight line.

questions.key_concept: First law: ∠i = ∠r.

questions.question_text: In a diagram showing reflection, which line represents the normal?

options.label: A
options.text: The line showing the path of the incident ray.

options.label: B
options.text: The line perpendicular to the reflecting surface at the point of incidence.

options.label: C
options.text: The line showing the path of the reflected ray.

options.label: D
options.text: The line along the reflecting surface.

questions.key_concept: The normal is a constructed perpendicular at the point of incidence.

questions.question_text: A light ray is incident normally (i=0°) on a plane mirror. According to the laws of reflection, what is the angle of reflection?
questions.key_concept: If i = 0°, then r = 0°. The ray retraces its path.

questions.question_text: In an experiment to verify the laws of reflection, the positions of pins P and Q (object) and R and S (image) are marked. What measurement verifies the first law?

options.label: A
options.text: Checking that all pin tips lie on the same plane (the drawing board).

options.label: B
options.text: Measuring angles AON and BON and finding they are equal.

options.label: C
options.text: Measuring the distance of the image behind the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: Checking that the lines AO and OB are straight.

questions.key_concept: Equality of ∠i and ∠r verifies the first law.

questions.question_text: How does the second law of reflection (coplanarity) differ from the first law in terms of experimental verification?

options.label: A
options.text: The first law is verified by angle measurement; the second is verified by ensuring all pins lie on the same flat surface (plane of paper).

options.label: B
options.text: The first law is for plane mirrors only; the second is for spherical mirrors.

options.label: C
options.text: The first law is about intensity; the second is about direction.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no way to verify the second law experimentally.

questions.key_concept: Coplanarity is verified by the setup geometry.

questions.question_text: Why must the mirror be kept vertical on the line MM1 in the verification experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure the incident ray is horizontal.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure the plane of incidence (the paper) is perpendicular to the mirror, making the normal lie in the plane of paper.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the image brighter.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the mirror from falling.

questions.key_concept: Vertical alignment ensures the experimental geometry accurately represents the laws in 2D.

questions.question_text: What is a real image?

options.label: A
options.text: An image that cannot be obtained on a screen.

options.label: B
options.text: An image formed when reflected rays actually meet.

options.label: C
options.text: An image that is always upright.

options.label: D
options.text: An image formed behind the mirror.

questions.key_concept: Real image is formed by actual intersection of rays.

questions.question_text: Which type of image is always virtual?

options.label: A
options.text: Image formed by a concave mirror for an object at infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: Image formed by a plane mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: Image formed by a concave mirror for an object at C.

options.label: D
options.text: Image formed by a concave mirror for an object beyond C.

questions.key_concept: Plane mirrors always form virtual images.

questions.question_text: A student says, 'A virtual image is just an illusion and cannot be photographed.' Is this correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because it cannot be projected.

options.label: B
options.text: No, a virtual image can be photographed because the camera lens can focus the diverging rays entering it.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, only real images affect photographic film.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but only if special film is used.

questions.key_concept: A virtual image is a point from which rays appear to diverge; cameras can record it.

questions.question_text: How can you practically distinguish between a real and a virtual image formed by a mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: By touching the mirror surface.

options.label: B
options.text: By trying to project it onto a screen. A real image will form on the screen.

options.label: C
options.text: By measuring its distance from the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: By checking if it is upright or inverted.

questions.key_concept: The screen test is a direct method.

questions.question_text: How do the paths of reflected rays differ for a real image and a virtual image formed by a mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: For a real image, rays converge to a point; for a virtual image, rays diverge but appear to come from a point.

options.label: B
options.text: For a real image, rays diverge; for a virtual image, rays converge.

options.label: C
options.text: In both cases, rays actually converge.

options.label: D
options.text: In both cases, rays actually diverge.

questions.key_concept: Converging vs. diverging rays after reflection define real vs. virtual.

questions.question_text: Why is the image formed on the retina of our eye considered real, even though we 'see' virtual images in mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: The eye lens forms a real image on the retina from the rays entering the eye, regardless of whether they came from a real or virtual object.

options.label: B
options.text: The retina itself acts as a mirror forming a virtual image.

options.label: C
options.text: Light rays stimulate the retina directly without forming an image.

options.label: D
options.text: Virtual images cannot be seen by the human eye.

questions.key_concept: Perception involves the eye forming a real image on the retina from incoming light.

questions.question_text: Where is the image of an object formed by a plane mirror located?

options.label: A
options.text: At the surface of the mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: As far behind the mirror as the object is in front.

options.label: C
options.text: At the focus of the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: At twice the object distance in front.

questions.key_concept: Image distance = Object distance (perpendicular).

questions.question_text: In a ray diagram for a point object and a plane mirror, how is the image point located?

options.label: A
options.text: By drawing one incident ray and its reflection.

options.label: B
options.text: By drawing at least two incident rays and producing their reflected rays backwards until they meet.

options.label: C
options.text: By drawing a line from the object parallel to the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: By measuring the focal length.

questions.key_concept: Intersection of extended reflected rays locates the virtual image.

questions.question_text: If an object is 10 cm in front of a plane mirror, and the mirror is moved 2 cm towards the object, what is the new distance between the object and its image?

options.label: A
options.text: 16 cm

options.label: B
options.text: 20 cm

options.label: C
options.text: 12 cm

options.label: D
options.text: 8 cm

questions.key_concept: Object distance becomes 8 cm, image distance behind mirror = 8 cm. Separation = 16 cm.

questions.question_text: A man 1.8 m tall wishes to see his full-length image in a plane mirror. What is the minimum vertical length of the mirror required?

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on his distance from the mirror.

questions.key_concept: Minimum mirror height is half the object height for a full view.

questions.question_text: How does the image formation for an extended object differ from that for a point object in a plane mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: For an extended object, images of individual points are found, and joining them gives the complete image. The process is the same in principle.

options.label: B
options.text: For an extended object, only one ray from each point is needed.

options.label: C
options.text: For a point object, the image is real; for an extended object, it is virtual.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference.

questions.key_concept: The image is built point-by-point using the same method.

questions.question_text: Why is it necessary to use at least two rays from an object point to locate its image in a plane mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: To verify the law of reflection for each ray.

options.label: B
options.text: Because a single reflected ray gives a direction but not a unique point; two lines are needed to fix a point in a plane.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the image brighter.

options.label: D
options.text: One ray is sufficient if it is incident normally.

questions.key_concept: Geometric principle: two intersecting lines determine a point.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of an image formed by a plane mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: Erect

options.label: B
options.text: Real

options.label: C
options.text: Laterally inverted

options.label: D
options.text: Of the same size as the object

questions.key_concept: Plane mirror images are virtual, not real.

questions.question_text: The image in a plane mirror is said to be 'laterally inverted'. What does this mean?

options.label: A
options.text: The top and bottom are swapped.

options.label: B
options.text: The left and right sides are interchanged.

options.label: C
options.text: The image is rotated by 90 degrees.

options.label: D
options.text: The image is upside down.

questions.key_concept: Lateral inversion refers to left-right reversal.

questions.question_text: A student writes the letter 'P' on a card and views its image in a plane mirror. What will the image look like?

options.label: A
options.text: P

options.label: B
options.text: b

options.label: C
options.text: d

options.label: D
options.text: q

questions.key_concept: Lateral inversion reverses the letter horizontally.

questions.question_text: Why are the letters on the front of an ambulance written laterally inverted (e.g., Ǝɯɐɔᴉꓷ∀)?

options.label: A
options.text: To make them look unique.

options.label: B
options.text: So that drivers ahead see them correctly (as 'AMBULANCE') in their rear-view mirrors.

options.label: C
options.text: To save paint.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is easier to read that way.

questions.key_concept: Lateral inversion by the mirror corrects the inverted writing.

questions.question_text: How does the 'perpendicular distance' of the image from the mirror compare to that of the object?

options.label: A
options.text: Image distance is always greater.

options.label: B
options.text: Image distance is always half.

options.label: C
options.text: They are equal.

options.label: D
options.text: Image distance depends on the angle of view.

questions.key_concept: Object distance in front = Image distance behind.

questions.question_text: If a person moves towards a plane mirror at a speed v, at what speed does the image appear to approach the person?

options.label: A
options.text: v

options.label: B
options.text: 2v

questions.key_concept: Relative speed between object and image is twice the object's speed relative to the mirror.

questions.question_text: What is the formula for the number of images 'n' formed by two inclined mirrors, if 360/θ is an integer?
questions.key_concept: General formula when n=360/θ is even OR object is symmetric: No. of images = n-1.

questions.question_text: Two mirrors are inclined at 90°. How many images of an object placed asymmetrically between them are formed?
questions.key_concept: For θ=90°, n=360/90=4 (even). Number of images = n-1 = 3 for all positions.

questions.question_text: Two mirrors are inclined at 72°. An object is placed symmetrically on the angle bisector. How many images are formed?
questions.key_concept: For θ=72°, n=360/72=5 (odd). For symmetric object, images = n-1 = 4.

questions.question_text: As the angle between two inclined mirrors is gradually increased from a small value, what happens to the number of images?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases

options.label: B
options.text: Decreases

options.label: C
options.text: Remains constant

options.label: D
options.text: First increases then decreases

questions.key_concept: Number of images is inversely related to the angle θ.

questions.question_text: How does the formula for the number of images differ when the object is placed symmetrically versus asymmetrically for an odd value of n = 360/θ?

options.label: A
options.text: For asymmetric: images = n; For symmetric: images = n-1.

options.label: B
options.text: For asymmetric: images = n-1; For symmetric: images = n.

options.label: C
options.text: It is always n-1 for both.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always n for both.

questions.key_concept: For odd n, symmetry causes two images to overlap, reducing count by one.

questions.question_text: Why are an infinite number of images formed when two plane mirrors are placed parallel to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the angle θ = 0°, and n = 360/0 is infinite.

options.label: B
options.text: Because light gets trapped between them forever.

options.label: C
options.text: Because each mirror has an infinite aperture.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the reflection is 100% efficient.

questions.key_concept: The formula conceptually leads to infinity as θ approaches 0.

questions.question_text: How many images are formed of an object placed between two parallel plane mirrors facing each other?

options.label: A
options.text: One

options.label: B
options.text: Two

options.label: C
options.text: A finite number (like 5 or 6)

options.label: D
options.text: An infinite number

questions.key_concept: Parallel mirrors (θ=0°) lead to infinite images.

questions.question_text: In a barber's shop, two mirrors are often placed on opposite walls. How are they arranged?

options.label: A
options.text: Perpendicular to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Parallel to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: At 60° to each other.

options.label: D
options.text: At 45° to each other.

questions.key_concept: Parallel mirrors allow seeing the back of the head via multiple images.

questions.question_text: Why do we not actually see an infinite number of images in parallel mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: Our eyes cannot resolve more than a few images.

options.label: B
options.text: With each reflection, some light is absorbed, so remote images become too faint.

options.label: C
options.text: The mirrors are never perfectly parallel.

options.label: D
options.text: Infinite images would require infinite time to form.

questions.key_concept: Light loss at each reflection limits visibility.

questions.question_text: All images formed by two parallel mirrors lie on a line that is:

options.label: A
options.text: Parallel to the mirrors.

options.label: B
options.text: The perpendicular drawn from the object to the mirrors.

options.label: C
options.text: At 45° to the mirrors.

options.label: D
options.text: Randomly distributed.

questions.key_concept: Images are aligned along the common normal from the object.

questions.question_text: How does the brightness of successive images in parallel mirrors compare?

options.label: A
options.text: All images are equally bright.

options.label: B
options.text: Brightness increases for later images.

options.label: C
options.text: Brightness decreases for later images.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the first image is bright; others are dark.

questions.key_concept: Light absorption at each reflection reduces intensity.

questions.question_text: In the context of parallel mirrors, why is the image formed by the first reflection from the back silvered surface the brightest?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it undergoes the fewest reflections and hence minimal light loss.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the back surface is more reflective than the front.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a real image.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our eyes are adapted to see it better.

questions.key_concept: Brightness is inversely related to the number of reflections.

questions.question_text: How many images are formed when an object is placed between two plane mirrors perpendicular to each other?
questions.key_concept: For θ=90°, number of images = 3.

questions.question_text: Where are the three images located relative to the mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: All behind one mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: One behind each mirror and one behind the intersection line.

options.label: C
options.text: They lie on a circle with centre at the mirrors' intersection.

options.label: D
options.text: They are randomly placed.

questions.key_concept: Images and object lie on a circle centred at the intersection point O.

questions.question_text: In perpendicular mirrors, why is the total number of images 3 and not 4?

options.label: A
options.text: Because one image is too dim to see.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the image formed by mirror 1 of the image in mirror 2 overlaps with the image formed by mirror 2 of the image in mirror 1.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the object blocks one possible image.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the formula n-1 gives 3 when n=4.

questions.key_concept: Two of the potential secondary images coincide.

questions.question_text: Which optical instrument uses two plane mirrors inclined at 90°?

options.label: A
options.text: Kaleidoscope

options.label: B
options.text: Periscope

options.label: C
options.text: Neither, a periscope uses parallel or 45° inclined mirrors.

options.label: D
options.text: Both use 90° mirrors.

questions.key_concept: Periscope uses mirrors at 45° to the vertical.

questions.question_text: How does image formation in perpendicular mirrors differ from that in parallel mirrors in terms of the object-image geometry?

options.label: A
options.text: In parallel mirrors, images are colinear; in perpendicular mirrors, they are co-circular.

options.label: B
options.text: In parallel mirrors, images are virtual; in perpendicular, one is real.

options.label: C
options.text: Parallel mirrors produce odd number of images; perpendicular produce even number.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no geometric difference.

questions.key_concept: Different arrangements lead to different geometric loci for the images.

questions.question_text: Why is the overlapping image in perpendicular mirrors not visually distinct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is formed by rays undergoing two reflections, and it coincides perfectly with another doubly reflected image from the other path.

options.label: B
options.text: It is much fainter and therefore invisible.

options.label: C
options.text: It is formed behind the mirrors where we cannot see.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a real image that gets projected away.

questions.key_concept: Symmetry leads to a single image from two equivalent optical paths.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a common use of a plane mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: As a rear-view mirror in vehicles.

options.label: B
options.text: As a looking glass.

options.label: C
options.text: To converge sunlight in a solar cooker.

options.label: D
options.text: To diverge light in street lamps.

questions.key_concept: Looking glass is the most basic use.

questions.question_text: In an optician's room, a plane mirror is used on the wall opposite the patient. What is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the room look bigger.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the effective viewing distance of the eye chart for the patient.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide better lighting.

options.label: D
options.text: To test for lateral inversion.

questions.key_concept: The mirror doubles the apparent distance of the chart.

questions.question_text: A student suggests using a plane mirror as the main reflector in a torch. Why is this not ideal?

options.label: A
options.text: A plane mirror produces a parallel beam only if the source is at infinity, which is not practical.

options.label: B
options.text: Plane mirrors are too expensive.

options.label: C
options.text: Plane mirrors absorb too much light.

options.label: D
options.text: Plane mirrors produce a diverging beam.

questions.key_concept: A plane mirror does not converge light; a concave mirror is needed for a directed beam from a near source.

questions.question_text: In a periscope, what is the angle of inclination of the two plane mirrors with respect to the vertical walls?
questions.key_concept: 45° inclination allows turning the line of sight by 90° twice.

questions.question_text: How does the use of a plane mirror in a solar cooker differ from its use in a periscope?

options.label: A
options.text: In a solar cooker, it redirects light; in a periscope, it redirects the line of sight.

options.label: B
options.text: In a solar cooker, it converges light; in a periscope, it diverges light.

options.label: C
options.text: A solar cooker uses a concave mirror, not a plane mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; both simply reflect light.

questions.key_concept: The purpose defines the application: energy collection vs. vision.

questions.question_text: Why is a plane mirror suitable for use in a kaleidoscope?

options.label: A
options.text: Its lateral inversion creates interesting patterns.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple reflections between inclined mirrors create symmetric patterns from random objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It magnifies the objects placed inside.

options.label: D
options.text: It filters specific colours.

questions.key_concept: Repeated reflection in a confined angular space generates geometric patterns.

questions.question_text: What is a concave mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: A mirror with a reflecting surface that bulges outwards.

options.label: B
options.text: A mirror with a reflecting surface that caves inwards.

options.label: C
options.text: A flat reflecting surface.

options.label: D
options.text: A mirror that always forms virtual images.

questions.key_concept: Concave = inward curving (like a cave).

questions.question_text: A spherical mirror is silvered on the outer surface of a hollow glass sphere. What type of mirror is it?

options.label: A
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined

questions.key_concept: Silvering the outer surface makes the inner hollow surface the reflecting surface (concave).

questions.question_text: A student says, 'A convex mirror converges light rays.' Why is this statement wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: A convex mirror diverges parallel rays; a concave mirror converges them.

options.label: B
options.text: Both mirrors converge light.

options.label: C
options.text: A convex mirror does not reflect light at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is correct.

questions.key_concept: Convex mirrors diverge incident parallel rays.

questions.question_text: Which type of mirror would you use as a 'security mirror' in a shop to see a wide area?

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Any spherical mirror

questions.key_concept: Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view.

questions.question_text: How does the reflecting surface relate to the silvered surface in concave vs convex mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: In concave, reflecting surface is the silvered inner surface; in convex, it is the silvered outer surface.

options.label: B
options.text: In concave, silvering is on the outer surface (bulging side); reflecting surface is the inner hollow side. In convex, silvering is on the inner surface; reflecting surface is the outer bulging side.

options.label: C
options.text: In both, silvering is on the inner surface.

options.label: D
options.text: In both, silvering is on the outer surface.

questions.key_concept: The side opposite to silvering becomes the reflecting surface.

questions.question_text: Why is a convex mirror not suitable for use as a shaving mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: It always forms a diminished image, making fine details hard to see.

options.label: B
options.text: It forms an inverted image.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not reflect light properly.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too expensive.

questions.key_concept: Magnification is needed for shaving; convex mirrors diminish.

concepts.concept_name: Terms Related to Spherical Mirrors (Pole, Centre, Radius, Aperture, Axis)

questions.question_text: What is the 'pole' of a spherical mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: The centre of the sphere from which the mirror is made.

options.label: B
options.text: The midpoint of the aperture.

options.label: C
options.text: The central point on the mirror's reflecting surface.

options.label: D
options.text: The point where light rays converge.

questions.key_concept: Pole (P) is the geometric centre of the mirror surface.

questions.question_text: The distance from the pole to the centre of curvature is called:

options.label: A
options.text: Focal length

options.label: B
options.text: Radius of curvature

options.label: C
options.text: Aperture

options.label: D
options.text: Principal axis

questions.key_concept: Radius of curvature (R) = distance PC.

questions.question_text: A student measures the diameter of the mirror's glass. Has he measured the aperture?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, aperture is the diameter of the mirror's surface through which light enters.

options.label: B
options.text: No, aperture is the radius of curvature.

options.label: C
options.text: No, aperture is the distance from pole to focus.

options.label: D
options.text: No, aperture is the thickness of the mirror.

questions.key_concept: Aperture is the size (diameter) of the mirror's exposed surface.

questions.question_text: In a spherical mirror, the normal at any point on its surface passes through:

options.label: A
options.text: The pole.

options.label: B
options.text: The centre of curvature.

options.label: C
options.text: The focus.

options.label: D
options.text: A point on the principal axis.

questions.key_concept: For a spherical surface, normals are radii, all passing through C.

questions.question_text: How do the 'principal axis' and the 'radius of curvature' differ?

options.label: A
options.text: The principal axis is a line; the radius of curvature is a distance along that line.

options.label: B
options.text: The principal axis is curved; the radius is straight.

options.label: C
options.text: The principal axis passes through the focus; the radius passes through the pole.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the same thing.

questions.key_concept: Axis is the reference line; radius is a specific measured length on it.

questions.question_text: Why is the concept of 'aperture' important in practical uses of spherical mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: A larger aperture allows more light to be collected, affecting brightness and image quality.

options.label: B
options.text: It determines the focal length of the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: It defines whether the mirror is concave or convex.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important for manufacturing, not for use.

questions.key_concept: Aperture relates to light-gathering power and aberrations.

concepts.concept_name: Focus and Focal Length of Spherical Mirrors

questions.question_text: What is the focus of a concave mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: A point behind the mirror where reflected rays appear to meet.

options.label: B
options.text: A point on the principal axis where rays parallel to the axis converge after reflection.

options.label: C
options.text: The centre of the sphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The midpoint of the radius of curvature.

questions.key_concept: Focus (F) is the real convergence point for parallel rays in a concave mirror.

questions.question_text: The focal length of a convex mirror is:

options.label: A
options.text: Positive according to sign convention.

options.label: B
options.text: Negative according to sign convention.

options.label: C
options.text: Zero.

options.label: D
options.text: Equal to its radius of curvature.

questions.key_concept: For convex mirror, f is positive (virtual focus behind mirror).

questions.question_text: A parallel beam of light, not parallel to the principal axis, is incident on a spherical mirror. Where will it be focused?

options.label: A
options.text: At the focus F on the principal axis.

options.label: B
options.text: At a point on the focal plane.

options.label: C
options.text: It will not focus at all.

options.label: D
options.text: At the centre of curvature.

questions.key_concept: Rays parallel to each other but not to the axis meet in the focal plane.

questions.question_text: If the radius of curvature of a concave mirror is 24 cm, what is its focal length?

options.label: A
options.text: 48 cm

options.label: B
options.text: 24 cm

options.label: C
options.text: 12 cm

options.label: D
options.text: 6 cm

questions.key_concept: f = R/2. For concave, f is negative, but magnitude is 12 cm.

questions.question_text: How does the nature of the focus differ between a concave and a convex mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: Concave has a real focus in front; convex has a virtual focus behind.

options.label: B
options.text: Concave has a virtual focus; convex has a real focus.

options.label: C
options.text: Both have real foci.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have virtual foci.

questions.key_concept: Real vs virtual focus is a fundamental difference.

questions.question_text: Why is the focal length of a spherical mirror half its radius of curvature?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a geometric property derived from the law of reflection and small aperture approximation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an experimental fact with no theoretical basis.

options.label: C
options.text: It is true only for convex mirrors.

options.label: D
options.text: It is true only if the object is at infinity.

questions.key_concept: The relation f = R/2 arises from geometry and the law of reflection.

concepts.concept_name: Ray Diagrams - Convenient Rays for Construction

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT one of the standard rays used to construct images in spherical mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: A ray passing through the centre of curvature.

options.label: B
options.text: A ray incident at the pole.

options.label: C
options.text: A ray making an arbitrary angle with the principal axis.

options.label: D
options.text: A ray parallel to the principal axis.

questions.key_concept: Standard rays have predictable paths after reflection.

questions.question_text: A ray incident on a concave mirror parallel to its principal axis will, after reflection:

options.label: A
options.text: Pass through the focus.

options.label: B
options.text: Appear to come from the focus.

options.label: C
options.text: Pass through the centre of curvature.

options.label: D
options.text: Retrace its path.

questions.key_concept: Key property of a concave mirror.

questions.question_text: For a convex mirror, a ray directed towards the centre of curvature C (which is behind the mirror) will, after reflection:

options.label: A
options.text: Retrace its path back along the same line.

options.label: B
options.text: Pass through the focus.

options.label: C
options.text: Reflect back along the same path because it is incident normally (since the normal at the point of incidence passes through C).

options.label: D
options.text: Become parallel to the principal axis.

questions.key_concept: A ray directed towards C is normal to the surface, so i=0, r=0.

questions.question_text: To locate the image of an object placed between F and P of a concave mirror, which two rays are most convenient to draw?

options.label: A
options.text: Ray parallel to axis and ray through C.

options.label: B
options.text: Ray through F and ray through C.

options.label: C
options.text: Ray incident at pole and ray parallel to axis.

options.label: D
options.text: Any two arbitrary rays.

questions.key_concept: These two rays are easy to draw and their reflected rays diverge; extending them backwards locates the virtual image.

questions.question_text: How does the path of a 'ray passing through the focus' differ between concave and convex mirrors during construction?

options.label: A
options.text: For concave: incident ray through F reflects parallel to axis. For convex: incident ray directed towards F (behind mirror) reflects parallel to axis.

options.label: B
options.text: For both, the incident ray actually passes through F.

options.label: C
options.text: For convex, such a ray cannot be drawn.

options.label: D
options.text: For both, the ray reflects back through F.

questions.key_concept: For convex, you draw a ray directed towards the virtual focus F behind the mirror.

questions.question_text: Why is it sufficient to draw just two of the standard rays to locate an image?

options.label: A
options.text: All rays from a point object will intersect at the same image point after reflection. Two lines uniquely determine that point.

options.label: B
options.text: The other rays are too complicated to draw.

options.label: C
options.text: The laws of reflection only apply to these two rays.

options.label: D
options.text: Drawing more rays would create confusion.

questions.key_concept: Geometric principle of point formation.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object at Infinity

questions.question_text: Where is the image formed by a concave mirror when the object is at infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: At the centre of curvature.

options.label: B
options.text: At the focus.

options.label: C
options.text: Between F and P.

options.label: D
options.text: Behind the mirror.

questions.key_concept: Parallel rays converge at F.

questions.question_text: The image of the sun formed by a concave mirror is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and highly diminished.

options.label: B
options.text: Real, inverted, and point-sized.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual, erect, and magnified.

options.label: D
options.text: Real, erect, and diminished.

questions.key_concept: Sun is at infinity, image is at F, point-sized.

questions.question_text: For an object at a very far but finite distance (like a tree), the image in a concave mirror is formed:

options.label: A
options.text: Exactly at the focus F.

options.label: B
options.text: In the focal plane, very close to F.

options.label: C
options.text: At the centre of curvature.

options.label: D
options.text: Behind the mirror.

questions.key_concept: For a far but finite object, rays are not perfectly parallel, so image is in focal plane near F.

questions.question_text: What is the nature of the image formed by a concave mirror for an object at infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: Virtual and erect

options.label: B
options.text: Real and inverted

options.label: C
options.text: Real and erect

options.label: D
options.text: Virtual and inverted

questions.key_concept: All real images formed by concave mirror (for object beyond F) are inverted.

questions.question_text: How does the image size for an object at infinity compare to that for an object at a far but finite distance?

options.label: A
options.text: Both are point images; no difference.

options.label: B
options.text: For infinity, it's a point; for far distance, it's highly diminished but has a finite size.

options.label: C
options.text: For infinity, it's magnified; for far distance, it's diminished.

options.label: D
options.text: For infinity, it's virtual; for far distance, it's real.

questions.key_concept: A true point object at infinity gives a point image. An extended far object gives a small, real image.

questions.question_text: Why is the image of a distant object formed in the focal plane of a concave mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: Because rays from a point on a distant object are nearly parallel, and parallel rays converge in the focal plane after reflection.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the object is at the centre of curvature.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mirror formula forces v = f when u is very large.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the image must be virtual.

questions.key_concept: Geometry of reflection for near-parallel rays.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object beyond C

questions.question_text: When an object is placed beyond the centre of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, where is the image formed?

options.label: A
options.text: Beyond C.

options.label: B
options.text: Between C and F.

options.label: C
options.text: At C.

options.label: D
options.text: Between F and P.

questions.key_concept: Image lies between F and C.

questions.question_text: The image formed when the object is beyond C is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and magnified.

options.label: B
options.text: Real, inverted, and diminished.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual, erect, and diminished.

options.label: D
options.text: Real, erect, and of same size.

questions.key_concept: Key characteristics for this position.

questions.question_text: As an object moves from infinity towards the centre of curvature C of a concave mirror, how does the image move?

options.label: A
options.text: Image moves from F towards C.

options.label: B
options.text: Image moves from C towards F.

options.label: C
options.text: Image moves from F towards P.

options.label: D
options.text: Image remains stationary at F.

questions.key_concept: Object moves in from infinity to C; image moves out from F to C.

questions.question_text: An object is placed at a distance of 30 cm from a concave mirror of focal length 10 cm. Where is the image formed?

options.label: A
options.text: 15 cm in front of mirror

options.label: B
options.text: 15 cm behind the mirror

options.label: C
options.text: 30 cm in front of mirror

options.label: D
options.text: 7.5 cm in front of mirror

questions.key_concept: u=-30, f=-10. Using mirror formula, v=-15 cm (between F and C).

questions.question_text: How does the image size for an object beyond C compare to that for an object at C?

options.label: A
options.text: Beyond C: diminished; At C: same size.

options.label: B
options.text: Beyond C: magnified; At C: diminished.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are magnified.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are diminished.

questions.key_concept: Size increases as object approaches C.

questions.question_text: Why is the image diminished when the object is beyond C?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the image is closer to the mirror than the object (|v| < |u|), leading to magnification |m| < 1.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the rays diverge after reflection.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the image is virtual.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror's aperture is small.

questions.key_concept: Magnification m = v/u. For real image, both u and v negative. If |v| < |u|, |m| < 1.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object at C

questions.question_text: When an object is placed at the centre of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, where is the image formed?

options.label: A
options.text: At F

options.label: B
options.text: At C

options.label: C
options.text: Between F and P

options.label: D
options.text: Behind the mirror

questions.key_concept: Object at C => Image at C.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a concave mirror when the object is at C is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and magnified.

options.label: B
options.text: Real, inverted, and of the same size.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual, erect, and magnified.

options.label: D
options.text: Real, erect, and diminished.

questions.key_concept: Key characteristics.

questions.question_text: For an object at C of a concave mirror, the linear magnification (m) is:
If a concave mirror has a focal length of 15 cm, where should an object be placed to get an image of the same size?

options.label: A
options.text: At 15 cm

options.label: B
options.text: At 30 cm

options.label: C
options.text: At 7.5 cm

options.label: D
options.text: At infinity

questions.key_concept: Same size image => object at C. R = 2f = 30 cm.

questions.question_text: How does the image formed when the object is at C serve as a reference point in the object-image movement relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the transition point where image size equals object size. For u > R, image is diminished; for u < R, image is magnified.

options.label: B
options.text: It is where the image changes from real to virtual.

options.label: C
options.text: It is where the image becomes erect.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no special significance.

questions.key_concept: C is the boundary for diminished vs magnified real images.

questions.question_text: Why does the image form exactly at C when the object is at C?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to symmetry: rays from a point on the object at C strike the mirror and reflect back through C because the normal at any point passes through C.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the focal length is half of C.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an experimental coincidence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror formula gives v = u when u = R.

questions.key_concept: Geometric symmetry ensures that all rays from C return to C.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object between C and F

questions.question_text: When an object is placed between C and F of a concave mirror, the image is formed:

options.label: A
options.text: Between F and P.

options.label: B
options.text: Beyond C.

options.label: C
options.text: At C.

options.label: D
options.text: At F.

questions.key_concept: Image lies beyond C.

questions.question_text: The image formed when the object is between C and F is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and diminished.

options.label: B
options.text: Real, inverted, and magnified.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual, erect, and magnified.

options.label: D
options.text: Real, erect, and magnified.

questions.key_concept: Key characteristics.

questions.question_text: As the object moves from C towards F, the image:

options.label: A
options.text: Moves from C away towards infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: Moves from C towards F.

options.label: C
options.text: Moves from F towards C.

options.label: D
options.text: Remains at C.

questions.key_concept: Object moves from C to F; image moves from C to infinity.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 20 cm from a concave mirror of focal length 15 cm. Where is the image formed?

options.label: A
options.text: 60 cm in front of mirror

options.label: B
options.text: 60 cm behind mirror

options.label: C
options.text: 8.6 cm in front of mirror

options.label: D
options.text: 8.6 cm behind mirror

questions.key_concept: u=-20, f=-15. Using mirror formula, v=-60 cm (beyond C).

questions.question_text: How does the image size for an object between C and F compare to that for an object at C?

options.label: A
options.text: Between C and F: magnified; At C: same size.

options.label: B
options.text: Between C and F: diminished; At C: magnified.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are magnified.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are same size.

questions.key_concept: Magnification increases as object moves from C to F.

questions.question_text: Why does the magnification become greater than 1 when the object is between C and F?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the image distance |v| becomes greater than the object distance |u|, leading to |m| = |v/u| > 1.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the image becomes virtual.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the focal length changes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is concave.

questions.key_concept: Magnification is directly related to the ratio of distances.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object at F

questions.question_text: When an object is placed at the focus (F) of a concave mirror, where is the image formed?

options.label: A
options.text: At C

options.label: B
options.text: At F

options.label: C
options.text: At infinity

options.label: D
options.text: Between F and P

questions.key_concept: Object at F => Image at infinity.

questions.question_text: The image formed when the object is at F is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and highly magnified.

options.label: B
options.text: Virtual, erect, and highly magnified.

options.label: C
options.text: Real, erect, and point-sized.

options.label: D
options.text: Virtual, inverted, and diminished.

questions.key_concept: Key characteristics.

questions.question_text: If an object is placed exactly at the focus of a concave mirror, the reflected rays are:

options.label: A
options.text: Parallel to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Diverging.

options.label: C
options.text: Converging at C.

options.label: D
options.text: Retracing their path.

questions.key_concept: Rays from F become parallel after reflection.

questions.question_text: To project a bright patch of light of the same size as the mirror's aperture on a screen, where should a point source be placed relative to a concave mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: At C

options.label: B
options.text: At F

options.label: C
options.text: Between F and P

options.label: D
options.text: Beyond C

questions.key_concept: Source at F gives parallel reflected rays, illuminating the entire aperture evenly onto a distant screen.

questions.question_text: How does the image at infinity for an object at F conceptually differ from the image of an object at infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: They are inverse processes: Object at infinity gives image at F; object at F gives image at infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: Both are virtual images.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are point images.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relation.

questions.key_concept: Principle of reversibility of light.

questions.question_text: Why is it said that the image is 'highly magnified' when the object is at F?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the image is at a very large distance (infinity), making the ratio |v/u| very large, hence magnification is very large.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mirror's curvature causes magnification.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the image is virtual.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not magnified; it is point-sized.

questions.key_concept: Magnification tends to infinity as v tends to infinity.

concepts.concept_name: Image Formation by Concave Mirror - Object between F and P

questions.question_text: When an object is placed between the focus (F) and the pole (P) of a concave mirror, the image is formed:

options.label: A
options.text: In front of the mirror, between F and C.

options.label: B
options.text: Behind the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: At infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: At C.

questions.key_concept: Image is virtual and behind the mirror.

questions.question_text: The image formed when the object is between F and P is:

options.label: A
options.text: Real, inverted, and magnified.

options.label: B
options.text: Virtual, erect, and magnified.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtual, erect, and diminished.

options.label: D
options.text: Real, erect, and magnified.

questions.key_concept: Key characteristics.

questions.question_text: As the object is moved from F towards P, the virtual image:

options.label: A
options.text: Moves from infinity behind the mirror towards the pole.

options.label: B
options.text: Moves from the pole towards infinity behind the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: Remains at a fixed point behind the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: Moves from behind the mirror to in front of it.

questions.key_concept: Object moves from F to P; virtual image moves from far behind towards the pole.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror is used as a shaving mirror. Where should the face be placed?

options.label: A
options.text: Beyond C

options.label: B
options.text: At C

options.label: C
options.text: Between C and F

options.label: D
options.text: Between F and P

questions.key_concept: To get an erect, magnified virtual image for grooming.

questions.question_text: How does the magnification for an object between F and P compare to that for an object between C and F?

options.label: A
options.text: Both are magnified (|m| > 1), but one is virtual (positive m) and the other is real (negative m).

options.label: B
options.text: Between F and P: diminished; between C and F: magnified.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are diminished.

options.label: D
options.text: Between F and P: real; between C and F: virtual.

questions.key_concept: Magnification can be >1 for both real and virtual images.

questions.question_text: Why is the image virtual when the object is between F and P?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the reflected rays diverge; they do not actually meet but appear to come from a point behind the mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the object is too close to the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the focal length becomes positive.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is concave.

questions.key_concept: Divergence of reflected rays defines a virtual image.

questions.question_text: For any position of a real object in front of a convex mirror, the image is always:

options.label: A
options.text: Real and inverted.

options.label: B
options.text: Virtual and erect.

options.label: C
options.text: Real and erect.

options.label: D
options.text: Virtual and inverted.

questions.key_concept: Convex mirrors always produce virtual, erect images.

questions.question_text: Where is the image formed by a convex mirror for an object at infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: At the focus F behind the mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: At the pole P.

options.label: C
options.text: At the centre of curvature C.

options.label: D
options.text: At infinity.

questions.key_concept: Parallel rays appear to diverge from F.

questions.question_text: As the object is moved from infinity towards the pole of a convex mirror, the image:

options.label: A
options.text: Moves from F towards P (behind the mirror).

options.label: B
options.text: Moves from P towards F.

options.label: C
options.text: Moves from C to F.

options.label: D
options.text: Remains at F.

questions.key_concept: Image shifts from focus to pole behind the mirror as object approaches.

questions.question_text: A convex mirror is preferred over a plane mirror as a rear-view mirror in vehicles because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Gives a magnified view.

options.label: B
options.text: Gives an erect and diminished view with a wider field of view.

options.label: C
options.text: Gives a clearer image.

options.label: D
options.text: Is cheaper.

questions.key_concept: Wider field of view is the key advantage.

questions.question_text: How does the image size in a convex mirror change as the object distance decreases?

options.label: A
options.text: Image size increases but remains smaller than the object (diminished).

options.label: B
options.text: Image size decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: Image size becomes larger than the object.

options.label: D
options.text: Image size remains constant.

questions.key_concept: Image is always diminished but grows as object comes closer.

questions.question_text: Why is the image formed by a convex mirror always diminished?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the image distance |v| is always less than the object distance |u| for a convex mirror, leading to |m| = |v/u| < 1.

options.label: B
options.text: Because convex mirrors absorb light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the image is virtual.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the focal length is positive.

questions.key_concept: Geometry of reflection ensures v < u in magnitude.

questions.question_text: According to the Cartesian sign convention, where is the origin for measuring distances for spherical mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: At the centre of curvature.

options.label: B
options.text: At the focus.

options.label: C
options.text: At the pole.

options.label: D
options.text: At the object.

questions.key_concept: All distances measured from the pole (P).

questions.question_text: For a concave mirror, the focal length (f) is taken as:

options.label: A
options.text: Positive

options.label: B
options.text: Negative

options.label: C
options.text: Zero

options.label: D
options.text: Infinity

questions.key_concept: Concave mirror has a real focus in front, so f is negative.

questions.question_text: A virtual image formed by a concave mirror has a image distance (v) that is:

options.label: A
options.text: Negative

options.label: B
options.text: Positive

options.label: C
options.text: Zero

options.label: D
options.text: Equal to u

questions.key_concept: Virtual image is behind the mirror, so v is positive.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 20 cm in front of a convex mirror of focal length 15 cm. Using sign convention, what are the values of u and f?

options.label: A
options.text: u = -20 cm, f = +15 cm

options.label: B
options.text: u = +20 cm, f = -15 cm

options.label: C
options.text: u = -20 cm, f = -15 cm

options.label: D
options.text: u = +20 cm, f = +15 cm

questions.key_concept: Object in front => u negative. Convex mirror => f positive.

questions.question_text: How does the sign of magnification (m) relate to the nature of the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive m => virtual and erect; Negative m => real and inverted.

options.label: B
options.text: Positive m => real and inverted; Negative m => virtual and erect.

options.label: C
options.text: Sign of m has no relation to nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Positive m => diminished; Negative m => magnified.

questions.key_concept: Sign of m indicates orientation.

questions.question_text: Why is the object distance (u) always taken as negative in mirror problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the object is always placed in front of the mirror (in the direction opposite to incident light as per convention).

options.label: B
options.text: Because the object is a source of light.

options.label: C
options.text: It is positive for virtual objects.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a random choice.

questions.key_concept: Sign convention defines distances against incident light direction as negative.

questions.question_text: What is the mirror formula?

options.label: B
options.text: u + v = f

options.label: C
options.text: uv = f

options.label: D
options.text: 1/f = u + v

questions.key_concept: Mirror formula relates object distance (u), image distance (v), and focal length (f).

questions.question_text: The linear magnification (m) for a mirror is given by:

options.label: A
options.text: m = v/u

options.label: B
options.text: m = -v/u

options.label: C
options.text: m = u/v

options.label: D
options.text: m = height of object / height of image

questions.key_concept: Magnification formula with sign.

questions.question_text: For a convex mirror, if u = -20 cm and f = +10 cm, using the mirror formula, v is calculated to be +6.67 cm. What does the positive sign for v indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: The image is real and in front of the mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: The image is virtual and behind the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: The calculation is wrong; v should be negative.

options.label: D
options.text: The image is at the pole.

questions.key_concept: Positive v indicates virtual image behind mirror for spherical mirrors.

questions.question_text: An object 2 cm high produces a real image 3 cm high in a concave mirror. What is the magnification?
questions.key_concept: m = h_i/h_o = -3/2 = -1.5. Negative for real, inverted image.

questions.question_text: How are the mirror formula and the magnification formula related?

options.label: A
options.text: They are independent formulas.

options.label: B
options.text: Magnification can be expressed in terms of f and v or f and u: m = f/(f-u) = (v-f)/f.

options.label: C
options.text: The magnification formula is derived by differentiating the mirror formula.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relation.

questions.key_concept: The formulas are interconnected through algebra.

questions.question_text: Why must the values of u, v, and f be substituted with their proper signs in the mirror formula?

options.label: A
options.text: To obtain a mathematically consistent result that correctly predicts the image position and nature for both concave and convex mirrors.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the formula only works with positive numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: To make calculations more complicated.

options.label: D
options.text: Signs are optional; magnitude is enough.

questions.key_concept: The sign convention is built into the formula's validity.

questions.question_text: Which mirror is used as a shaving mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Any spherical mirror

questions.key_concept: Concave mirror gives erect, magnified virtual image when object between F and P.

questions.question_text: In a torch, the reflector is a:

options.label: A
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Concave lens

questions.key_concept: Concave mirror produces a parallel or converging beam when source is at focus.

questions.question_text: A student suggests using a convex mirror as a dentist's head mirror to concentrate light. Why is this not suitable?

options.label: A
options.text: A convex mirror diverges light; it cannot concentrate light on a small area.

options.label: B
options.text: A convex mirror is too small.

options.label: C
options.text: A convex mirror forms real images.

options.label: D
options.text: A convex mirror is too expensive.

questions.key_concept: Concentration requires convergence, which a convex mirror cannot provide.

questions.question_text: Why is a convex mirror used as a rear-view mirror in vehicles?

options.label: A
options.text: It gives a wider field of view, allowing the driver to see more traffic behind.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives a magnified image of vehicles behind.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives a clearer image than a plane mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: It is cheaper to manufacture.

questions.key_concept: Wider field of view is the primary advantage.

questions.question_text: How does the use of a concave mirror in a solar cooker differ from its use in a torch?

options.label: A
options.text: In a solar cooker, a large concave mirror focuses parallel sunlight onto a small area (heating). In a torch, a small concave mirror collimates light from a point source at focus into a parallel beam (illumination).

options.label: B
options.text: There is no difference; both concentrate light.

options.label: C
options.text: A solar cooker uses a plane mirror; a torch uses a concave mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: A solar cooker uses a convex mirror.

questions.key_concept: Same optical principle applied in reverse: converging vs collimating.

questions.question_text: Why might a plane mirror sometimes be preferred over a convex mirror for a rear-view mirror, despite the narrower field of view?

options.label: A
options.text: A plane mirror gives an undistorted, true-to-size image, making it easier to judge actual distances and sizes of following vehicles.

options.label: B
options.text: A plane mirror is always safer.

options.label: C
options.text: A plane mirror is cheaper.

options.label: D
options.text: A plane mirror can be used at night.

questions.key_concept: Trade-off between field of view and image fidelity.

questions.question_text: You bring your face close to a mirror. The image is upright and of the same size, and does not change size when you move. The mirror is:

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined

questions.key_concept: Plane mirror gives same-size, erect image unaffected by distance.

questions.question_text: You see an upright and magnified image of your face in a mirror. When you move away, the image size increases. The mirror is:

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Either concave or convex

questions.key_concept: Concave mirror can give magnified virtual image; moving away (towards F) increases magnification.

questions.question_text: A mirror forms an upright and diminished image. When you move away from it, the image size decreases further. What type of mirror is it?

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined

questions.key_concept: Convex mirror always gives diminished, erect image. Moving away makes object distance larger, image smaller.

questions.question_text: To distinguish a concave mirror from a convex mirror without touching, you bring your face close. What observation indicates a concave mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: The image is inverted.

options.label: B
options.text: The image is erect and magnified, and grows larger as you move slightly away.

options.label: C
options.text: The image is erect and same size.

options.label: D
options.text: The image is erect and diminished, and shrinks as you move away.

questions.key_concept: The specific behaviour of magnification change with distance is key.

questions.question_text: How does the test for distinguishing mirrors rely on the relative positions of object (face) and the mirror's focal point?

options.label: A
options.text: For a concave mirror, when face is between P and F, image is virtual, erect, magnified. Moving away changes magnification. For convex, image is always virtual, erect, diminished.

options.label: B
options.text: It does not rely on focal point; it relies on curvature.

options.label: C
options.text: The focal point is only relevant for convex mirrors.

options.label: D
options.text: The test only works if the face is beyond C.

questions.key_concept: The test exploits the different image formation rules based on object position relative to F.

questions.question_text: Why is it impossible to get an inverted image of your face in a convex mirror during the distinguishing test?

options.label: A
options.text: Because a convex mirror always forms a virtual, erect image for any real object position.

options.label: B
options.text: Because your face is too close.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the focal length is positive.

options.label: D
options.text: Because convex mirrors are flat.

questions.key_concept: Fundamental property of convex mirrors.

concepts.concept_name: Difference Between Concave and Convex Mirrors (Summary)

questions.question_text: Which mirror has a reflecting surface that caves inwards?

options.label: A
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Both (a) and (b)

questions.key_concept: Basic definition.

questions.question_text: A mirror that always diverges incident parallel light rays is a:

options.label: A
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: D
options.text: None of these

questions.key_concept: Convex mirrors diverge parallel rays.

questions.question_text: Which statement about image formation is TRUE for both concave and convex mirrors?

options.label: A
options.text: They can both form real and virtual images.

options.label: B
options.text: They both obey the laws of reflection.

options.label: C
options.text: They both always form diminished images.

options.label: D
options.text: They both have a real focus.

questions.key_concept: All mirrors obey the fundamental laws of reflection.

questions.question_text: For which mirror can the image be magnified, real, and inverted?

options.label: A
options.text: Plane mirror

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Convex mirror

options.label: D
options.text: Both (b) and (c)

questions.key_concept: Only concave mirrors can produce such images (object between C and F).

questions.question_text: How do the uses of concave and convex mirrors generally differ based on their image-forming properties?

options.label: A
options.text: Concave mirrors are used where convergence or magnification is needed (shaving, focusing). Convex mirrors are used where a wide field of view is needed (security, rear-view).

options.label: B
options.text: Concave mirrors are used for wide view; convex for magnification.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are used interchangeably.

options.label: D
options.text: Concave mirrors are only used in scientific instruments.

questions.key_concept: Application is driven by the mirror's optical properties.

questions.question_text: Why is a convex mirror not suitable for applications requiring a focused, high-intensity spot of light?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it diverges light rays, spreading them out rather than concentrating them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it absorbs most of the light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it forms real images.

options.label: D
options.text: Because its focal length is too short.

questions.key_concept: Divergence vs convergence is the key differentiating factor.
